keyTakeAways: Nicholas Rossi, a 38-year-old man, was convicted of raping two women in northern Utah in 2008 and sentenced to between five and life in prison, reflecting the severity of the crimes.
Rossi allegedly faked his death in 2020 by publishing an online obituary claiming he died of non-Hodgkin lymphoma, which allowed him to evade justice for years.
He used multiple aliases, including Arthur Knight, and evaded capture through international travel, including a stay in Scotland where hospital staff recognized his tattoos from an Interpol notice.
Utah’s efforts to clear its rape kit backlog in 2018 were instrumental in identifying Rossi through DNA evidence.
The victim described the trauma of the assault and emphasized the need for accountability and safety, highlighting the real-world impact of sexual violence.
Rossi is a known serial abuser of women and has a history of evading legal responsibility, including a prior sex-related conviction in Ohio and failure to register as a sex offender in Rhode Island.
The case underscores the dangers of false death narratives and the importance of DNA database systems in solving cold cases.
The sentencing reflects both the gravity of the crimes and the broader societal need for accountability in sexual assault cases.

summaryOfNewsArticle: Nicholas Rossi, a 38-year-old man from Rhode Island with a history of sexual abuse and evasion of justice, was convicted of raping two women in northern Utah in 2008. After being identified through a decade-old DNA rape kit in 2018, Rossi allegedly faked his death in 2020 by publishing an online obituary claiming he died of non-Hodgkin lymphoma. He fled to Scotland, where he was arrested in 2023 after hospital staff recognized his tattoos, including the Brown University crest, from an Interpol notice. After a protracted extradition process, he was returned to Utah in January 2024 and sentenced by District Judge Barry Lawrence to a prison term of five years to life. The case highlights the dangers of false death narratives, the importance of DNA databases in solving cold cases, and the broader societal need for accountability and safety in sexual assault cases.
title: Man accused of faking his own death and fleeing the US after rape charges gets at least five years in prison
